resource.title: Imaging Recommendations for Suspected Pulmonary Embolism
resource.description: Comprehensive imaging recommendations for suspected Pulmonary Embolism (PE) considering patient-specific risks due to severe CKD and hypotension.

note.text: Patient has Stage 4 CKD (eGFR 22) and significant hypotension (MAP 57), increasing risk of CIN and hemodynamic decompensation with contrast.
Critical hyperkalemia (K+ 5.8 mEq/L) requires urgent management before contrast administration.
V/Q scan is the preferred alternative to CTPA in patients with severe renal dysfunction and hemodynamic instability, as it avoids iodinated contrast.
Aggressive renal protection strategies are mandatory if contrast-enhanced imaging is pursued.
Low-dose screening CT protocols are not suitable for acute diagnostic imaging of PE.
Bedside echocardiography offers a contrast-free assessment for PE and cardiac strain.

detail.description: Prioritize a Ventilation/Perfusion (V/Q) scan for suspected Pulmonary Embolism (PE) given the patient's severe CKD (eGFR 22) and hypotension (MAP 57), avoiding iodinated contrast.

If CT Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA) is absolutely essential and non-contrast alternatives are insufficient, implement aggressive pre-hydration with isotonic saline (if no contraindications like heart failure), use iso-osmolar, low-iodine concentration contrast, and administer the minimum effective volume. Correction of hyperkalemia (K+ 5.8 mEq/L) must be prioritized before contrast administration.

coding.display: Computed tomography angiography of pulmonary artery (procedure)

detail.description: Consider bedside transthoracic echocardiography as an alternative to assess for right heart strain and rule out massive PE in the setting of hemodynamic instability, avoiding contrast entirely.
If CTPA is performed, a low-dose, non-contrast CT chest protocol for lung cancer screening should NOT be selected as it is inappropriate for acute PE evaluation.

resource.name: CT_CHEST_LOW_DOSE_SCREENING
resource.title: Low-Dose CT Chest — Lung Cancer Screening
resource.description: Low-dose CT of lungs targeting <3 mGy radiation dose while maintaining image quality.

note.text: Contrast Timing: N/A — non-contrast low-dose protocol.
Renal Safety Notes: Ideal in patients with renal dysfunction due to non-use of contrast.

Rationale for Selection: This protocol is included as a non-contrast option, which is generally preferred given the patient's renal status. However, it is NOT suitable for acute evaluation of shortness of breath or chest pain suggestive of PE.

resource.name: CT_CHEST_ANGIO_PULMONARY_EMBOLISM
resource.title: CT Pulmonary Angiography (Chest CTA for PE)
resource.description: CT angiography timed for pulmonary arterial phase (6–13 sec post-contrast) to evaluate pulmonary arteries for embolism.

note.text: Contrast Timing: Pulmonary arterial phase: ~6–13 sec post-injection.
Contrast Dose: Weight-based; ~100–150 mL iodinated contrast (300 mg I/mL); follow ACR Manual.
Renal Safety Notes: Ensure contrast-to-eGFR ratio <1.1 g/(mL/min); if eGFR <30, consider non-contrast alternatives or weigh risks carefully.

Rationale for Selection: This protocol is indicated for the patient's symptoms. However, its use is highly cautioned due to severe CKD and hypotension. If chosen, stringent renal protection measures and hyperkalemia management are imperative, and alternative modalities like V/Q scan should be considered first.
